Project Description  The  Restructuring  of  the  Technical  Education  and  Vocational 
Training  System  Project  (Project)  will  help  the  Department  of 
Education  and  the  Department  of  Labor  and  Manpower  in 
Balochistan  Province  in  Pakistan  to  reform  the  technical 
education  and  vocational  training  (TEVT)  system  covering 
postsecondary technician education at the polytechnic level, mid-
level technical and vocational training for students after grade 8, 
and  livelihood  training  for  out-of-school  youth  and  women.  It 
comprises  three  components:  (i)  institutional  development,  (ii) 
improvement of quality and relevance of TEVT, and (iii) access 
and equity enhancement. The Project will focus on (i) improving 
the capacity of TEVT  institutions to be more competitive and 
responsive to labor market needs by emphasizing public-private 
partnerships, on-the-job training, and counseling services for job 
placements; and (ii) introducing performance-based management 
and  management  development  programs  for  more  efficient 
delivery of TEVT programs. The relevancy and quality of TEVT 
programs will be improved through competency-based training, 
teacher  training,  provision  of  learning  resources,  and  quality 
control. The Project will support rural poor and women through 
new programs and facilities, livelihood training for rural areas, 
and  entrepreneurship  training  and  support  for  access  to 
microcredit for self-employment. 
   
Rationale  Balochistan  needs  to  increase  investment  in  education  and 
training. The total literacy rate for both sexes of 36.0% (53.0% for 
males and 15.0% for females) is the lowest among all provinces 
in  the  country,  with  a  wide  disparity  between  genders  and 
between rural (30.0%) and urban (70.0%) areas. Poverty may be 
as high as 41.3% compared with the national rate of 32.1%. To 
reduce  poverty,  the  Government  of  Pakistan  is  working  to 
develop skilled workers and generate employment especially in 
small  and  medium  enterprises  using  indigenous  natural 
resources. While the province has a high unemployment rate, 
existing job opportunities often are unfilled due to lack of trained 
personnel. International employment opportunities are increasing 
for skilled workers, especially in middle eastern countries and 
Malaysia.  To  prepare  workers  for  both  these  environments 
improvements of the internal and external efficiency of the TEVT 
system  are  urgently  needed.  Efforts  to  consolidate  and 
strengthen TEVT programs and additional investments to make

the  TEVT  system  more  responsive  and  competitive  will  help 
improve  the  prospects  of  TEVT  trainees  when  they  seek 
employment or self-employment.  
   
Objectives   The Project’s goal is to contribute to the Government’s overall 
poverty  reduction  strategy  by  enhancing  competitiveness  of 
TEVT and employability of its graduates in line with emerging 
market needs. Focusing on Balochistan, the Project’s specific 
objectives  are  to  (i)  restructure  and  strengthen  institutional 
capacity,  efficiency,  and  autonomy  of  TEVT  institutions;  (ii) 
improve  quality  and  relevance  of  TEVT  programs;  and  (iii) 
enhance access and equity to better quality TEVT, particularly for 
rural poor and women. 
 
The  Project  will  support  the  Department  of  Education  and 
Department of Labor and Manpower in provincial government of 
Balochistan (PGB) to restructure their organizational setup, and 
strengthen institutional capacity to provide better quality TEVT 
programs  that  are  relevant  and  responsive  to  the  needs  of 
industries. The Project will support TEVT institutions to improve 
their  planning  and  management  through  greater  autonomy  to 
provide  higher  quality  and  more  relevant  TEVT  programs. 
Providing  training  for  teachers  and,  more  relevant  learning 
resources, introducing competency-based training, and improving 
quality  control  will  increase  the  quality  of  TEVT  programs. 
Support to new facilities and new TEVT programs, and provision 
of livelihood training programs will provide better access to TEVT 
programs for the rural poor and women.

v
  In rural areas, the Project will expand and improve the quality of 
TEVT educational opportunities of livelihood programs for out-of-
school  youth  and  adults  who  want  to  acquire  skills  for 
employment or to start their own businesses. Nongovernment 
organizations will plan and implement the livelihood programs. 
Innovative features such as identification of training needs and 
trades for self-employment will help meet local needs as well as 
those of the outside market. Credit facilitation support will allow 
TEVT  graduates  to  access  microcredit  facilities  to  start  small 
businesses and help generate income and employment in the 
communities. All these measures will help reduce poverty in the 
province especially in rural areas where educational opportunities 
are still very limited. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  faces  four  possible  risks:  financial,  institutional, 
policy, and economic. Firstly, the Government’s effort to expand 
TEVT  without  adequate  focus  on  consolidating  and  ensuring 
effective services at the existing training institutes could erode 
the financial and technical base needed to sustain the effective 
operation of these institutions. The Project supports measures to 
strengthen the capacity and autonomy of TEVT institutions and 
seeks  PGB’s  assurances  for  adequate  recurrent  budgets  and 
autonomy of TEVT institutions to enable them to manage their 
financial resources based on the needs. 
 
Secondly,  TEVT  institutions  lack  autonomy  and  effective 
leadership  to  make  them  responsive  to  labor  market  needs. 
While most TEVT institutions have IMCs or CMCs depending on 
the type of institution, only a few of these committees are active 
largely because of their poor governance structure, weak role of 
principals,  and  lack  of  time  among  IMC/CMC  members.  The 
Project  includes  a  management  development  program  and 
performance-based  management  system  to  strengthen  the 
capacity of principals, teachers, and staff of TEVT institutions. 
 
  Thirdly, while the federal policy on TEVT envisages substantial 
improvement in the quality, management, and financing of TEVT 
programs,  translating  this  into  action  is  not  possible  without 
linking the performance of TEVT institutions with improvement 
plans,  targets,  and  policy  stipulations.  The  Project  aims  to 
increase efficiency and effectiveness of TEVT institutions through 
innovative measures such as quality assurance and accreditation 
systems,  a  performance-based  management  system,  and 
examination reform; and will seek PGB’s assurances to align key 
TEVT policies at the provincial level. 
 
  Fourthly, the economy is not growing fast enough to absorb more 
graduates from TEVT institutions. Related to this is the limited 
involvement of the private sector in TEVT institutions. The Project 
supports much greater involvement of the private sector through 
IMCs, CMCs, production units, guidance counseling, and more 
organized labor market information.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Restructuring  of  the  Technical  Education  and 
Vocational Training System Project (Balochistan). 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Pakistan’s strong economic growth in the 1980s—averaging 6.5%—slowed considerably 
in 1990s to an average of 4.6%. Key social indicators, particularly for education, also stagnated, 
comparing unfavorably with other countries at similar levels of development. However beginning 
in fiscal year (FY) 2003, the economy began to recover. The growth rate increased to 5.1%, and 
in FY2004 it is estimated at 6.4%. To achieve the significant poverty reduction targets in the 
poverty reduction strategy1 for Pakistan, the annual economic growth rate must be sustained 
above 6%, particularly because population growth remains high. 
 
3.  The provincial government of Balochistan (PGB) faces dual problems of low educational 
attainment and high incidence of poverty among its population. The total literacy rate of those 
10 years of age and above is 36.0% (53.0% for males and 15.0% for females), and the net 
primary school enrollment rate (2001) is about 37%—the lowest rates in all of Pakistan. Literacy 
rates between genders and urban (70%) and rural (30%) areas (the majority (77%) live in rural 
areas)  differ  dramatically.  School  participation  is  low  at  66%  gross  enrollment  in  primary 
education for both sexes (81% for boys and 48% for girls). Only about 63% of students in grade 
1 reach grade 10 after repeating several grades, indicating that many children leave school 
without appropriate skills and knowledge. 
 
4.  In 2001, the Federal Bureau of Statistics reported Balochistan’s poverty level to be 
22.8%. However, the poverty reduction strategy for Balochistan notes that the 22.8% poverty 
figure was “largely a statistical aberration,” and if past trends had continued, poverty would have 
risen to 41.3% in 1998/99 against a national average of 32.1%. High levels of poverty have led 
to large variations in educational attainment among different economic groups. For instance, the 
net enrollment in primary education was only 24% for the lowest economic quintile compared 
with 39% for the highest. Key factors for the rapid increase in poverty during the 1990s were (i) 
the slowdown in economic growth; (ii) negligible increase in per capita income; (iii) limited job 
growth and absorption capacity in the formal sector; (iv) high labor costs in the formal sector 
that  lead  to  overexpansion  of  the  low  productivity  informal  sector,  thus  putting  downward 
pressure on wages in the informal sector; (iii) limited opportunities for unskilled youth to obtain 
on-the-job training and skills; and (iv) low quality of social services, particularly education and 
health.  
 
5.  Pakistan’s labor force grows at a rate of over 2.0% per annum, while employment grows 
much  more  slowly.  The  official  rate  of  unemployment  is  between  5.4–5.9%  whereas  the 
underemployment rate (those working less than 35 hours a week) is estimated at about 12%. 
The  situation  is  much  worse  in  Balochistan,  with  unemployment  over  10%  (over  21%  for 
females) and about 40% labor force participation rate (about 17% for females). Most workers 
are self-employed or unpaid family workers; wage earners account for less than one third. 
Among urban unemployed youths between the ages of 10 and 24, the majority are either

illiterate or with qualifications below grade 10. The national Government is working to develop 
skilled workers and to generate employment especially in small and medium enterprises using 
indigenous  natural  resources.  The  international  demand  for  skilled  workers  is  increasing, 
especially in middle-eastern countries and Malaysia. The Project will assist PGB in its efforts to 
reduce poverty by providing greater access to quality technical education and vocational training 
(TEVT) programs especially in rural areas and for women, and facilitate access to credit to help 
TEVT  graduates  seek  employment  or  engage  in  self-employment  in  small  and  medium 
enterprises. 
 
6.  Balochistan’s TEVT subsector comprises two polytechnics—one for women established 
under the Technical Education Project (TEP)2—with over 1,000 students (about 435 women) 
and about 130 teachers; and 11 technical and vocational training centers (TVTCs), with about 
1,300 students. Only 1 TVTC is for women. Opportunities in the local labor market are limited 
and  Balochistan  has  been  less  successful  than  the  other  provinces  in  accessing  the 
international job market. Given the low participation rate in general education, low completion 
rates at primary and secondary levels, and limited involvement of the private sector in the 
economy and educational provision, PGB will have to adopt a two-pronged strategy: (i) improve 
general school education as a priority, focusing on girls and rural children; and (ii) provide 
selective support to training programs as many youths lack the necessary employment skills. As 
general education improves and provides more core life skills, support for TEVT will shift to 
more practical aspects of training. However, for a few years, until general education improves 
significantly, TEVT will have to focus on formal and nonformal TEVT programs as a complement 
to general education, and not as a substitute. This approach benefits the poor who need a 
second chance for life skills. TEVT must be viewed from a holistic perspective to fill in gaps in 
the context of overall educational needs. 
 
7.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) strategy for development assistance to Pakistan3 
focuses  on  poverty  reduction  through  sustainable  pro-poor  growth,  inclusive  social 
development,  and  good  governance.  It  highlights  the  need  for  comprehensive  human 
development strategies, devolution of services for human development, and education reforms 
for  quality.  In  particular,  it  supports  the  Education  Sector  Reforms  Action  Plan  of  the 
Government of Pakistan (Government) linked with the devolution process to promote public-
private partnerships. It also emphasizes the need to move away from Government-based, 
umbrella-based projects to more focused province-specific support. ADB’s strategy is in line 
with the Government’s National Education Policy, Education Sector Reforms Action Plan, and 
poverty reduction strategy, and stresses the important role that TEVT plays in producing skilled 
workers and technicians for the economy. The Ten-Year Perspective Development Plan 2001–
11 points out that options for technical, commercial, and vocational education in the country are 
still limited and sets the introduction of technical education at secondary and postsecondary 
levels as a priority. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
8.  Despite  some  progress  in  the  province,  TEVT  still  faces  several  challenges  and 
constraints,  which  need  to  be  addressed  systematically.  Appendix  1  provides  the  project 
framework, Appendix 2 the problem tree, and Appendix 3 a brief sector analysis. Some of the 
key issues and opportunities are discussed in the following sections.

9.  Weak  Institutional  Capacity.  The  two  polytechnics  are  under  the  Directorate  of 
Colleges, Higher, and Technical Education, which is responsible for planning, coordination, and 
supervision of both higher (i.e., general) and technical education. Examinations of students of 
diploma of associate engineer (DAE) programs, on the other hand, are organized by the Board 
of  Intermediate  and  Secondary  Education  (BISE),  which  is  responsible  for  conducting 
examinations for students from elementary to technical levels. As more polytechnics will be 
established under the Government’s Ten-Year Perspective Development Plan 2001–11 and the 
National Education Policy 1998–2010, the planning, coordination, and supervision functions for 
technical education need to be integrated under one agency. PGB has approved in principle the 
establishment  of  a  separate  Directorate  of  Technical  Education  (DTE)  in  anticipation  of 
expanding technical education in the province. Given the important role of this directorate in 
improving integration and coordination of TEVT institutions and programs, support for PGB in 
establishing this directorate is urgently required.  
 
10.  Low Internal and External Efficiency. The internal efficiency of polytechnic programs, 
while still a concern, has improved over the years. The dropout rates in the Government 
Polytechnic Institute for Boys (GPIB) averaged around 8% between 1997 and 2002. For the 
Government Polytechnic Institute for Women (GPIW), the dropout rate was about 12% in 2002, 
the first year of its operation. The high dropout rate results in wastage of resources and must be 
seriously addressed. The average percentage of students who pass external examinations as 
per BISE records is quite low at 46% in 2002 compared with 65% in 1997.  
 
11.  External efficiency as measured by the number of graduates who obtain employment 
after graduation also needs to be improved. Based on the labor market survey conducted under 
an advisory technical assistance,4 graduates of DAE programs spent from 1–2 years seeking 
employment before they found a job. In addition, they required an additional 3–6 months training 
in the industry after recruitment. While limited employment opportunities in the private sector are 
partly responsible for this difficulty finding employment, the quality and relevance of technical 
education is also to blame (para. 15). Entrepreneurship training could be introduced to prepare 
students for self-employment, and job placement services provided for graduating students. 
Both polytechnics and TVTCs could also offer short-term modular training programs for people 
who want to acquire skills and start businesses of their own. Given that the Government 
encourages semiskilled and skilled workers to find out-of-country employment especially in the 
Middle East and Malaysia, TEVT must play an important role in preparing for this. 
 
12.  Weak Linkage with Labor Market Needs. Although the demand for some traditional 
trades  and  technologies  (electrical,  electronics,  and  mechanical)  and  new  trades  and 
technologies (computer, information, and telecommunication) is expected to remain high, the 
mismatch  between  skills  of  TEVT  graduates  and  labor  market  demand  means  that  TEVT 
graduates have difficulty getting jobs even when opportunities exist. A labor market survey 
confirms that (i) not enough graduates are being produced in some of the traditional courses 
and limited training opportunities are available in new technologies; and (ii) even if the courses 
are  available,  their  relevance  is  affected  by  lack  of  labor  market  information,  limited  and 
inappropriate practical training component, and lack of the necessary linkages with industries.  
 
13.  The lack of sharing of information and resources between industry and TEVT institutions 
creates a gap between users and producers of skilled workers, which in turn affects the quality 
of TEVT programs and graduates. As a result, students fail to acquire employable skills during 
their  training.  To  forge  a  closer  link  between  industries  and  TEVT  institutions,  institute

management  committees  (IMCs)  have  been  established  at  polytechnics  and  center 
management committees (CMCs) at TVTCs. However, so far the IMCs and CMCs have not 
proved effective in drawing needed assistance and cooperation from industries. To increase 
their  effectiveness,  their  roles,  functions,  and  responsibilities  need  to  be  strengthened, 
leadership enhanced, and resource base improved. In addition, the committees, which include 
significant industry representation, need to focus on providing on-the-job training for students, 
industrial training for TEVT teachers, and job placement services for TEVT graduates. 
 
14.  Limited Access to and Options for TEVT. With just two polytechnics and 11 technical 
and vocational training centers in the province of over 7 million people, Balochistan lags the 
other provinces in access to and options for TEVT. In Balochistan one TEVT institution is built 
for about every 535,000 people, compared with one TEVT institution for 142,000 in Sindh, and 
311,000 in Punjab. This indicates the need to expand coverage with a particular focus on 
women and vulnerable groups. The two polytechnic institutes are located in Quetta and the 11 
training centers are in major districts. Although the polytechnics provide a district quota for 
nomination of students to their training programs, the number, normally 5 seats per district, is 
still low compared with the number of people and secondary school graduates who opt for 
technical education. To address the issue of limited access and options, both the Government 
and PGB plan to establish additional polytechnics, especially in economic growth centers. This 
expansion plan is elaborated in the National Education Policy 1998–2010 and the Education 
Sector Reforms Action Plan 2001–2005.  
 
15.  Poor Quality of Examinations. TEVT students in DAE programs must take external 
examinations conducted by BISE. The examinations consist of written tests (60%), practical 
tests  (20%),  and  internal  tests  given  by  the  lecturers  (20%).  The  problem  is  that  TEVT 
institutions “teach for the exam” rather than for transferring practical skills. Because of lack of 
facilities and proper mechanisms, practical tests for certain subjects are given orally instead of 
requiring students to actually perform the required tasks. For the written tests, a total of 167 
theory papers were prepared for the 10 technologies offered at the two polytechnics in 2002. 
The  quality  of  the  content,  coverage,  types  of  questions,  practical  tests,  supervision  and 
administration of the examinations, marking of papers, and announcements of results all need 
to be improved. In addition, the structure of the examinations for each technology needs to be 
modified to be in line with the DAE curriculum, which specifies 60% for practical exercises and 
40% for the theory of the subject matters. 
 
16.  Role of the Public Sector. The TEVT system is highly supply driven and needs to 
develop  mechanisms  to  respond  to  market  needs.  Different  government  agencies  are 
responsible  for  the  provision  of  TEVT  programs  resulting  in  lack  of  coherence  in  and 
fragmentation of TEVT programs. However, with the strong support for devolution and PGB’s

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objective 
 
20.  The goal of the Project is to contribute to the Government’s overall strategic goal of 
poverty reduction by enhancing competitiveness of the TEVT system and employability of its 
graduates in line with emerging market needs. Focusing on Balochistan, the Project’s specific 
objectives are to (i) restructure and strengthen institutional capacity, efficiency, and autonomy of 
TEVT  institutions,  (ii)  improve  quality  and  relevance  of  TEVT  programs,  and  (iii)  enhance 
access and equity to better quality TEVT particularly for the rural poor and women. 
   
B.  Components and Outputs 
 
21.  The Project has three components: (i) institutional development, (ii) improvement of 
quality and relevance of TEVT, and (iii) access and equity enhancement. 
 
1.  Component 1: Institutional Development 
 
22.  This  component  will  help  restructure  and  strengthen  the  capacity  of  key  agencies 
responsible for policy development, planning, and management of the TEVT system in line with 
the Government’s key policies on reforming TEVT. The policy implications are presented under 
assurances (para. 73) and Appendix 6. This component covers three subcomponents.  
                 
a.  Strengthening Organization and Management Capacity  
  of TEVT Facilities 
 
23.  This subcomponent will strengthen organization and management capacity of the DTE 
under the Department of Education (DOE) and the Directorate of Manpower Training (DMT)

6  
under the Department of Labor and Manpower (DOLM). The Project will help (i) establish the 
DTE and strengthen its capacity in research and development (R&D), and (ii) institutionalize a 
quality  assurance  and  accreditation  system  under  the  DTE  and  DMT.  The  DTE  will  be 
responsible for development of policies, plans, and guidelines for institutional development and 
management,  quality  assurance,  R&D,  curriculum  development,  and  staff  development 
programs for technical education. The new DTE will be provided with a modest building, core 
staff, office equipment, and furniture. The R&D cell to be transferred to the DTE will receive 
training for staff; funds and equipment for selective research studies and surveys; and support 
for developing a full-fledged computerized management information system (MIS), labor market 
information  system  (LMIS),  and  project  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation  system 
(PPMES). The R&D cell will undertake some research and studies and engage appropriate 
research and academic institutions through a competitive process to carry out more complex 
research and studies such as labor market surveys and tracer studies. 
 
24.  The Project will support the institutionalization of a quality assurance and accreditation 
system under BISE for DAE programs, and trade testing board (TTB) under DMT for technical 
and vocational training programs. The Project will help BISE and TTB develop accreditation 
standards; a quality assurance system; and mechanisms including criteria, guidelines, manuals, 
and instruments for assessing and improving the quality of TEVT programs. Both BISE and TTB 
will receive equipment, training of personnel, and seed money to implement the system in their 
respective organization for both public and private TEVT institutions. The Project will also 
provide training for staff of polytechnics and TVTCs to establish an internal quality assurance 
unit at all TEVT institutions.  
 
b.  Implementing a Performance-Based Management System 
  for TEVT Facilities 
 
25.  The  Project  will  support  the  implementation  of  a  performance-based  management 
system in all TEVT institutions to promote accountability and efficiency in TEVT management. 
TEVT institutions will be required to prepare a 5-year institutional development plan, which will 
serve as the basis for budgetary allocations. Indicators such as enrollment, number of poor 
students in the programs, dropout rate, passing rate, and employment of graduates will be 
developed and used to assess efficiency and effectiveness of the institutions. The Project will 
provide funds to develop guidelines, criteria, and operation manuals for implementation of the 
system. Block funds from the Project will be allocated to provide incentives to selected high 
performing project facilities to undertake additional development. Gradually, TEVT institutions 
will develop the capacity to be more autonomous in managing their own operations. PGB will 
issue a notification to institutionalize the performance-based management system, which will be 
tied to budgetary allocations after project completion. Consulting services will be provided to 
develop and implement the system. 
 
c.  Strengthening Capacity of TEVT Facilities 
 
26.  The Project will (i) help strengthen TEVT capacity to plan, manage, and assess their 
operation and performance; (ii) establish DACs, and strengthen the capacity and resources of 
IMCs and CMCs; and (iii) implement management development programs (MDPs) for key TEVT 
officials including principals and key staff members. 
 
27.  Strengthening Capacity of TEVT Institutions. In line with the Government’s TEVT 
policy and devolution plan, the Project will help TEVT institutions develop capacity to plan, 
manage,  and  evaluate  their  own  operations  and  performance.  Principals  and  staff  will  be

7
provided  training  in  key  competencies  to  enable  them  to  develop  a  5-year  institutional 
development  plan  that  clearly  identifies  objectives,  targets,  staffing  requirements,  capacity-

for medium- and long-term development of their institutions. Staff development programs in the 
areas  of  market  analysis,  financial  management,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  organization 
management, and social marketing will be implemented under the Project. By 12 months after 
project implementation begins, TEVT institutions will also prepare a resource mobilization and 
utilization plan to ensure sustainability of new investments. An institution will be selected to 
carry  out  the  capacity-building  programs  at  TEVT  institutions.  Eventually,  the  institutional 
development plan will serve as a basis for the disbursements of project resources to the 
institutions to implement programs and activities that will contribute to the achievements of the

months  after  project  implementation  begins)  a  TEVT  rationalization  plan,  teacher  career 
development plan, and a plan for gradual autonomy of TEVT institutions to strengthen the TEVT 
system.  
 
28.  Establishing DACs and Strengthening the Capacity and Resources of IMCs and 
CMCs. The Project will support the establishment of DACs in districts with polytechnics and 
TVTCs. The DAC, comprising representatives of industries, educational institutions, and the 
communities, will help promote closer collaboration between local industries, the communities, 
and the institutions in order to mobilize resources and support from the private sector to the 
TEVT institutions. In addition, it will support the IMCs and CMCs to provide support in linking 
TEVT institutions with industries on a district-wide basis. The Project will help strengthen the 
IMCs and CMCs in all TEVT institutions. Modest financial resources will be provided on a 
competitive basis, based on proposals submitted by the IMCs and CMCs, as seed money to 
enable them to carry out their functions more effectively. Capacity-building programs will be 
conducted for members of the committees. In addition, procedure manuals will be developed for 
reference of the committees and TEVT institutions.  
 
29.  Implementing  MDP  at  TEVT  Facilities.  Qualified  local  management  institutions 
including universities and higher education institutions will be invited to submit proposals to 
implement the MDP for staff of TEVT institutions under a management contract. The MDP will 
help improve the capability of principals, teachers, and staff to assume more responsibilities and 
autonomy in planning, management, and effective resource mobilization and utilization in their 
institutions. The MDP will cover such key areas as market and competitiveness analysis for 
demand-based  training,  financial  planning  and  management,  performance  improvement, 
institutional development, proposal preparation and project implementation, and evaluation of 
training  programs.  The  MDP  will  support  TEVT  institutions  based  on  the  institutional 
development plans to enhance the competitiveness of polytechnics and TVTCs.

31.  CBT  System  Development.  The  Project  will  help  develop  a  framework  and 
mechanisms for introducing the CBT6 system in TEVT institutions, and provide training to 
teachers to prepare lessons, instructional materials, and learning modules for their subjects in 
the CBT format with a focus on helping students to practice and acquire the skills that meet 
industry  standards.  Each  project  institution  will  be  required  to  nominate  courses  in 
technologies/trades to be converted into the CBT format for funding under the Project. At a 
minimum, each technology/trade will convert at least one course into the CBT format. The 
Project  will  support  this  initiative  by  providing  funds  to  teachers  who  submit  proposals  to 
develop lessons, instructional materials, and learning modules and packages in the CBT format

participation of the teachers and institutions with incentives initiated under the Project. 
 
32.  Examination Reform. Currently one of the responsibilities of BISE, established in 1977 
as an autonomous corporate body, is conducting examinations at the DAE level for students of 
polytechnics. The current examination practices are inflexible and not conducive to promoting 
student acquisition of practical skills required by industries. PGB will issue a notice to allow the 
Project to reform the examination system by preparing a framework and an operation manual to 
introduce a new system in which TEVT institutions will be given autonomy and responsibilities to 
conduct skills tests based on the CBT format. Teachers will be trained on how to prepare 
reliable and valid skills tests and practical examinations. The Project will also provide support to 
BISE  and  the  TTB  to  help  strengthen  capacity  and  improve  the  quality  of  the  theoretical 
examinations.  This  will  include  training  examiners  and  paper  setters,  computerizing  the 
examination system, developing an examination items bank, strengthening the examination 
management system, and providing office equipment and materials.

3.  Component 3: Access and Equity Enhancement 
 
42.  This component covers three areas to provide greater access to TEVT among the rural 
poor and women, especially those who lack opportunities to obtain skills training in formal TEVT 
programs.  
 
    a.  Introducing Equivalency and Certification System 
 
43.  The Project will help BISE and TTB to establish an equivalency and certification system 
with appropriate mechanisms for skills assessments based on the CBT standards. The system 
will give qualifying credits and issue trade certificates to students, trainees, and workers who 
pass the external examinations and assessments. The equivalency system will provide learning 
opportunities for those who have acquired other forms of prior learning as well as opportunities 
for skilled workers to obtain formal qualifications for career development and for employment in 
other  countries.  BISE  and  DMT  will  be  responsible  for  developing,  implementing,  and 
institutionalizing the equivalency and certification system for their respective agency. Skills 
assessment centers will be established at selected polytechnics and TVTCs. They will be 
provided with necessary infrastructure, equipment, and materials to help launch the equivalency 
and certification system; and social marketing activities to increase awareness and promote

better  understanding  and  acceptance  of  the  equivalency  and  certification  system  among

44.  Nonformal  training  programs  to  improve  livelihood  and  provide  employable  skills  to

compete for the funds and may choose to partner with NGOs. Subjects and topics will be based

allowed to retain and utilize the money from the Project and the fees to supplement their regular 
budgets. The nonformal livelihood training programs could eventually be made a regular feature 
of TEVT institutions as outreach/community services and to promote employment opportunities 
and livelihood employment among the poor in the province.

C.  Special Features 
 
47.  The Project supports PGB to consolidate TEVT programs, with cautious expansion 
linked to greater emphasis on market needs and women and rural poor. The consolidation effort 
emphasizes integrating and strengthening TEVT programs in existing institutions, focusing on 
filling all teacher vacancies, providing in-service training to teachers, improving quality and 
relevance  of  existing  programs,  and  allocating  adequate  budget  for  basic  operation  and 
maintenance before embarking on any large-scale expansion.  
 
48.  The Project emphasizes improving institutional efficiency through greater autonomy and 
ensuring effective leadership of TEVT institutions, greater partnership with the private sector in 
running evening classes and production units, and supporting performance-based management 
to make TEVT institutions more competitive, relevant, accountable, and responsive to labor 
market needs.  
 
49.  The Project emphasizes equity and access by supporting TEVT programs for females 
and the poor in rural areas. The Project is also exploring the possibility of introducing double 
shifts in selected TEVT institutions to run programs for both female and male students. The 
Project supports construction of selected hostel facilities for women who come from rural areas. 
The  Project  supports  more  relevant  livelihood  programs  (for  example,  fisheries,  livestock, 
agriculture, food preservation, and crafts) and access to microcredit for rural females and rural 
poor, and also supports the engagement of NGOs to provide services to out-of-school youth, 
women, and rural poor.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits 
 
63.  The  Project  focuses  on  consolidating  and  strengthening  existing  TEVT  programs  in 
Balochistan with cautious expansion by improving the capacity of TEVT institutions to become 
more competitive; providing better quality and more relevant skills to TEVT students in selected 
technologies; and helping improve equitable access among women and rural poor. The Project is 
designed to make TEVT more responsive to labor market needs and support the graduates to 
either find suitable initial employment in the local or international markets without long waiting time 
or to seek microcredit to start their own businesses. The Project’s staff development activities 
benefit teachers of the participating TEVT institutions by improving their practical and subject skills. 
All these inputs are expected to improve external efficiency of the TEVT system in the form of 
greater employment opportunities and higher earnings.  
 
64.  The  direct  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  over  6  years  will  be  about  10,000  students 
enrolled (about 2,500 graduates) in four polytechnics (two existing and two new), about 10,000 
students (about the same number of graduates) in 14 training centers (11 existing and 3 new), 
and about 20,000 out-of-school youth and adults to receive nonformal livelihood training. Other 
direct beneficiaries include over 150 teachers and principals in polytechnics and 600 in training 
centers, and about 250 IMC and CMC members. Based on the demographic profile of the 
province and anticipated expansion of TEVT, about 75% of the total direct beneficiaries are 
anticipated to come from rural areas, about 25% will be female, and about 40% will be from 
economically poor families. Poorer communities will benefit mostly from the livelihood programs, 
but also from the DAE and trades programs since most of these students are unable to proceed 
to general education. 
 
65.  The DAE and trades programs will benefit small and medium enterprises in the province 
through the introduction of improved learning methods, resource materials, and modern up-to-
date equipment. The focus on practical application and linkages with the industry for both the 
students and teachers will allow polytechnics and training centers to learn from the industry, 
while the industry will be able to get more skilled graduates to improve their productivity. TEVT 
graduates  will  also  be  able  to  prepare  for  the  international  market,  which  has  provided 
employment opportunities to many Pakistanis and contributes to the overall economy through 
increasing remittances. Livelihood training will provide opportunities in rural areas for out-of-
school youths and adults to acquire skills for employment and to start their own ventures. With 
the support of NGOs, the provision of programs that are in demand and have much greater 
flexibility should be possible. Credit facilitation support will allow TEVT graduates to access 
microcredit  to  start  small  ventures  and  help  generate  income  and  employment  in  the 
communities. All these measures are expected to help reduce poverty in the province especially 
in rural areas where educational opportunities are still very limited. The Project also addresses 
the needs of women by expanding opportunities and increasing access to quality TEVT through 
the strengthening of existing polytechnic institutes and training centers, and supporting the 
establishment of two new training centers.  
 
B.  Project Risks 
 
66.  The  Project  faces  four  possible  risks:  financial,  institutional,  policy,  and  economic. 
Appendix 14 identifies potential risks and proposed mitigation measures. First, PGB’s effort to 
expand TEVT without adequate focus on consolidating and ensuring effective services at the 
existing training institutes could erode the financial and technical base needed to run these

17
institutions effectively. The Project supports measures to strengthen the capacity and greater 
autonomy of TEVT institutions and seeks PGB’s assurances for adequate recurrent budgets 
and necessary provision to enable TEVT institutions to manage their financial resources based 
on the needs of the institutions. Economic and financial analyses are presented in Appendix 14. 
 
67.  Second, TEVT institutions lack autonomy and many lack effective leadership to make 
them responsive to labor market needs. While most TEVT institutions have IMCs or CMCs 
depending on  the  type  of  institution,  only  a few  of  these  committees  are  effective  largely 
because of weak governance structure and weak role of the principals. The Project includes an 
MDP and performance-based management system to strengthen the capacity of principals, 
teachers, and staff of TEVT institutions. The Project also supports capacity-building programs 
for members of IMCs and CMCs together with modest financial assistance to make them more 
effective in providing support to TEVT institutions. 
 
68.  Third, while the federal policy on TEVT envisages substantial improvement in the quality, 
management, and financing of TEVT programs, this will not be possible without linking the 
performance of TEVT institutions with improvement in plans, targets, and policy stipulations. 
The  Project  aims  to  increase  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  TEVT  institutions  through 
innovative measures such as a quality assurance and accreditation system; performance-based 
management  system;  and  examination  reform  to  enable  the  institutions  to  focus  on 
improvement  of  quality,  relevance,  efficiency,  and  effectiveness  of  their  programs  and 
operations. The Project also seeks PGB assurances to align key TEVT policies at the provincial 
level. 
 
69.  Fourth,  the  economy  is  not  growing  fast  enough  to  absorb  more  TEVT  graduates. 
Related to this is the limited involvement of the private sector in TEVT institutions. Unless the 
private sector, which is going to be the main provider of employment, is more actively engaged, 
TEVT graduates will continue to have difficulty finding jobs. The Project supports much greater 
involvement  of  the  private  sector  through  IMCs  and  CMCs,  production  units,  guidance 
counseling, more organized labor market information, and credit facilitation for self-employment. 
 
C.  Environment 
 
70.  Category B. An initial environment examination was undertaken and the summary is in 
supplementary Appendix B.  
 
D.  Social Analysis 
 
71.  The  Project  aims  to  increase  equity  in  and  effectiveness  of  TEVT  programs  by 
supporting three training centers and one polytechnic for women who will mostly come from 
rural areas. The focus on improving quality and organization of all TEVT institutions will benefit 
students largely from poorer families from rural areas. The summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Appendix 15.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  General Education 
 
1.  General  education  in  Pakistan  can  be  divided  into  elementary,  secondary,  higher 
secondary, and higher education. Elementary education can be further subdivided into primary 
(grades 1–5) and middle levels (grades 6–8). Secondary comprises grades 6–10 and higher 
secondary grades 11–12. A baccalaureate in general science or humanities takes another 2 
years  after  the  higher  secondary  school  certificate  making  a  total  of  14  years,  whereas 
programs on engineering and medicine take longer. 
 
2.  The Ministry of Education at the federal level is responsible for policy, planning and 
overall educational standards. It also has control over the curriculum for grades 1–12. The 
provincial department of education is responsible for education in each province. Recently, 
under the devolution plan, responsibility for education was devolved to the districts where the 
executive district officer for education is responsible for supervision and promotion of education.  
   
B.  Technical Education and Vocational Training 
 
3.  Technical Education and Vocational Training (TEVT) in Pakistan can be divided into 
three subcomponents: prevocational or school level, technical education, and vocational training 
(TEVT), and higher engineering and technology education. The history of the introduction and 
integration of prevocational and vocational courses into the general school education dates 
back to the early 1950s and many experiments have been conducted. However, these efforts 
haven’t had a significant impact on general school education, which from the period of colonial 
rule was geared toward producing clerks and other office workers rather than technicians, 
engineers, and scientists. The education policy of 1972–80 suggested a major shift from general 
education  and  emphasized  relating  education  to  the  world  of  work.  This  resulted  in  the 
introduction of agro-technical studies (wood work, metal work, and electricity), agriculture, and 
home economics in urban, rural, and girls’ middle schools respectively in grades 6–8. In grades 
9–10 introduction of vocational courses of various groups such as agriculture, commerce, home 
economics, and industrial arts was encouraged. More recently, this approach is reaffirmed 
under the National Education Policy and Education Sector Reform Program. 
 
4.  The rapid growth of the TEVT subsector is due to the Government’s desire to increase 
access of rural youths and women to technical education and vocational training to improve 
their job skills and means of livelihood. The lack of places in the universities also led to 
expansion of the subsector, as it became an alternative channel for youth and school leavers. 
This  resulted  in  the  social  demand  for  more  opportunities  for  and  access  to  TEVT.  The 
Government assumed the main responsibility of providing TEVT to youths with little participation 
of the private sector. Only during the last few years has there been a growing trend toward 
encouraging participation of the private sector in TEVT provision. Under the Education Sector 
Reforms Program, a number of incentive schemes have been introduced to enlist private sector 
participation in education and training. 
 
5.  Vocational Training. Vocational training caters to unemployed youths who lack skills 
and those who either drop out of the school system or fail to qualify for admission in the 
polytechnic institutes and colleges. Expansion in vocational training took place during 1980–
1990, and included establishing several training centers and upgrading a number of old ones 
across the country. The Ministry of Youth Affairs also established 20 youth vocational centers. 
The expansion of vocational training and the establishment of national and provincial training

boards took place through the promulgation of the National Training Ordinance in 1980. This 
also emphasized qualitative improvement in vocational training, initiation of training programs 
for  women  in  nontraditional  trades,  and  closer  involvement  of  employers  in  planning  and 
administration of vocational training.   
   
6.  The duration as well as entry qualifications for different vocational training programs vary 
widely. Training programs range from a few weeks to 2 years and entry qualifications vary from 
middle to secondary school pass. Vocational courses are more practically oriented compared 
with technical education. The curriculum of vocational courses comprises 80% practical and 
20% theory. Graduates are expected to perform semiskilled and skilled jobs in various sectors 
or can be self- employed. 
 
7.  There are only 11 technical and vocational training centers (TVTCs) in 10 of the 26 
districts in Balochistan, the largest province in physical size, offering training in 19 trades. The 
training centers operate under the aegis of the Department of Labor and Manpower (DOLM). 
The duration of courses varies from 4 weeks to 12 months. Enrollments in the 11 public training 
centers during the 2001–2002 session in both regular and evening programs totaled around 
1,300 trainees. In addition, 294 trainees enrolled in short courses offered at the TVTC in Quetta, 
the women’s TVTC in Quetta, and the TVTC in Khuzdar. Of the 11 training centers, only 1 is for 
females.  In  addition,  23  private  training  institutions  offer  mainly  computer  training  and are 
registered with the Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education (BISE). 
 
8.  Technical Education. Technical education refers to postsecondary school training of 
middle level supervisory technicians carried out in polytechnic institutes. These technicians 
serve as a link between engineers and technologists and the skilled and semiskilled workers 
below. The rapid growth of the TEVT subsector was the result of the Government’s desire to 
increase access of rural youth and women to technical education and vocational training to 
improve their job skills and means of livelihood. The lack of places in the universities also led to 
expansion of the subsector, as it became an alternative channel for youth and school leavers. 
This resulted in the social demand for more opportunities for and access to TEVT.  
 
9.  A 3-year course leading to diploma of associate engineer (DAE) is the main program of 
the polytechnic institutes in the country. The DAE curriculum comprises 60% practical and 40% 
theory. The polytechnic institutes offer a wide range of training programs in traditional as well as 
new and emerging technologies. While the number of technologies offered in various institutions 
in other three provinces ranges from one in the case of monotechnic institutes and up to eight in 
bigger polytechnics, there are only two polytechnics in Balochistan (one for boys and one for 
girls) with over 1,000 students enrolled. The polytechnic institute for women in Quetta was 
established only in 2002 under the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-funded Technical Education 
Project. For a province with over 7 million people, this is considered inadequate and compares 
very unfavorably with other provinces. 
 
10.  The persistent demand of DAE holders for the extension of facilities to higher education 
in the field of technology resulted in the introduction in late 1970s of a baccalaureate degree in 
technology, with a uniform pattern throughout the country. The baccalaureate program (pass 
course) takes 2 years, 1 year on-the-job experience and 1 year teaching for DAE holders; and 
the  honors  baccalaureate  is  also  2  years,  again  one  year  on-the-job  training  and  1  year 
schooling, for those who passed the pass course). To offer the baccalaureate program, a 
number  of  polytechnic  institutes  were  upgraded  to  the  level  of  college  of  technology.  In 
Balochistan, the polytechnic institute for males was also upgraded to offer the program. This 
initiative is considered important for two reasons: (i) to provide some opportunities to DAE

about 50% have only DAE qualification. 
 
C.  Governance, Structure, and Management of TEVT 
 
11.  The TEVT system lacks operational integrity as a system. The components of TEVT 
were  divided  and  dispersed  to  become  separate  and  uncoordinated  functions  of  many 
organizations.  Traditionally,  technical  education  was  placed  under  the  responsibility  of  the 
provincial and district education departments, while vocational training was with the directorate 
of human resources training under DOLM. As a result, policy of training was duplicated, and  
planning and monitoring were poor. The merging of TEVT into a single system has become an 
international benchmark in addressing the paradigm shift in human resource development. Over 
the past 10 years a major realignment of TEVT systems of Asia Pacific countries has occurred 
as  a  human  resource  management  strategy  of  globalization.  This  international  trend  and 
realization internally, has led to changes in Pakistan as well. Much progress has been made 
recently  in  Punjab  with  the  initiative  of  the  Punjab  government  to  establish  the  Technical 
Education and Vocational Training Authority, responsible for all training programs under a 
corporate  structure.  The  North-West  Frontier  Province  is  moving  in  this  direction,  while 
Balochistan and Sindh are watching this development carefully. 
 
12.  In Balochistan, the TEVT system is not integrated into one body. Technical education is 
attached to the Directorate of Colleges, Higher, and Technical Education under the Department 
of Education, while technical and vocational training is provided by the 11 TVTCs under the 
DMT, which in turn is under DOLM. The organization of the TEVT system was not affected by 
the devolution plan and TEVT institutions lack autonomy. Although the provincial government of 
Balochistan  (PGB)  intends  to  establish  a  directorate  of  technical  education  under  the 
Department of Education to manage and organize technical education, a plan to merge all 
TEVT institutions under one institution similar to the North-West Frontier Province is also being 
discussed. 
 
D.  Demand and Supply of Skilled Workers and Technicians 
 
13.  Traditionally  most  TEVT  institutions,  particularly  the  polytechnic  institutes,  were 
established to train the workforce for Government departments and public sector organizations 
where their qualifications (certificate/diplomas) served as proof of competence. Until recently 
very little attempt has been made to involve the end users in the operation, management, and 
program delivery, and to align the course contents to the needs of industries. This failure has 
contributed to the marginalization of TEVT institutions with employers showing little interest in 
extending cooperation to the institutions due to lack of interactions between industries and 
TEVT institutions. Consequently, TEVT programs are seen as out of step with the needs and 
expectations of the workplace. 
 
14.  A  labor  market  survey  conducted  in  2003  under  an  advisory  technical  assistance 
supported by ADB provided important implications for the TEVT system. First, the graduates 
identified a lack of industrial training skills and inadequate practical content as a key weakness 
of  the  TEVT  programs,  followed  by  shortage  of  equipment,  insufficient  consumables  and 
learning materials, and poorly prepared teachers. Consistent with this observation, the majority 
of the enterprises rated practical skills, troubleshooting, report writing and communication skills, 
and  safety  consciousness  as  poor.  Graduates  who  got  employment  had  to  undergo  an 
additional 3 months of training by their employers.

15.  Second, the survey indicated that the annual future demand for skilled workers and 
technicians  as  high  in  electrical,  mechanical,  electronics,  computer  and  information,  and 
telecommunications; and as moderate in civil and construction, auto and diesel, refrigeration 
and air-conditioning, plastic, rubber, and petroleum trades and technologies. 
 
16.  Third, the survey indicated that there is mismatch of skills between those imparted in 
TEVT institutions and those required by the industry, which may be associated with lack of 
timely updating of curriculum, lack of teachers with appropriate expertise, or shortage of funds. 
This may also be due to an inflexible training system, which is difficult to change to meet the 
needs of the labor market. The mismatch also comes from gaps in the competencies imparted 
by the TEVT institutions and those demanded by the industry, such as lack of skills in practical 
aspects, troubleshooting, report writing, and communication.   
 
E.  Key Issues and Challenges in TEVT 
 
17.  The analysis of the TEVT system vis-à-vis the emerging needs of the economy indicates 
several areas for improvement. First, consolidation of TEVT programs is urgently needed to 
ensure that existing programs are organized and managed effectively in response to emerging 
labor market needs, both for the local and international markets. Second, given that Balochistan 
has very limited opportunities for TEVT due to limited involvement of the private sector, PGB 
needs to make targeted investments to expand and improve TEVT quality, particularly for 
women and rural poor. PGB needs to play a strategic role to ensure an effective and responsive 
TEVT  system  through  policy  reforms,  regulation,  targeted  investments,  monitoring,  and 
evaluation; and providing a greater role for nongovernment organizations and private sector, 
which  is  in  line  with  the  national  education  policy,  education  sector  reform,  and  poverty 
reduction strategy paper. Third, PGB regulatory function needs to ensure application of core 
principles such as linkages with industry, practical orientation of TEVT programs, provision of 
labor  market  information  and  counseling  services  to  TEVT  students  and  graduates, 
performance-based management to target funds, and greater flexibility to introduce changes in 
teaching and learning in response to emerging labor market needs. Finally, providing greater 
operational autonomy to TEVT institutions to plan and manage their programs effectively is very 
important. This approach promotes effective leadership and performance-based management 
and allows TEVT providers to become more responsive and competitive.

A.  National Education Policy 
 
1.  The National Education Policy (NEP), 1998–2010, stipulates 19 policy provisions for

into  seven  policy  areas;  namely,  (i)  improving  planning,  management,  coordination,  and

recovery  for  self–reliance,  and  private  sector  participation  in  the  provision  of  TEVT;  (iii) 
strengthening evaluation, examinations, and accreditation of TEVT programs and institutions; 
(iv) improving the skills and qualification of teachers through in-service training and provision of 
liberal in-service training facilities for teachers; (v) regular revising and upgrading curricula, 
introducing emerging technologies including computer education as a compulsory component of 
the curriculum of technical education, introducing a modular approach to provide continuing

4.  Consideration of Design Alternatives. The Project faced mainly two options: either to 
support a large-scale expansion given the Government’s ambitious plan of providing access to 
TEVT at the district and tehsil levels, or to focus more on ensuring effective functioning of 
existing facilities before embarking on a large-scale expansion. While support for large-scale 
expansion would be in line with the Government’s policy stipulation under the perspective plan 
2001–2011 and education sector reform (2001–2005), and would receive big buy-in from the 
provincial  government  of  Balochistan  (PGB),  it  would  be  very  difficult  to  sustain  such  an 
approach due to limited budgets available for essential recurrent expenditures and lack of 
effective models of TEVT institutions. The Project has therefore taken a middle path of cautious 
expansion with a strong emphasis on consolidating existing TEVT institutions. Some expansion 
is necessary as Balochistan lags Punjab and Sindh significantly in terms of access to TEVT, 
particularly among women and the rural poor. The balance between cautious expansion and 
consolidation allows PGB to improve the quality and efficiency of existing TEVT institutions with 
limited expansion in the most viable towns and districts, focusing on women and rural poor. 
 
5.  An investment loan modality is proposed since PGB is not yet ready to embark on a 
more complex design. Given the experience of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) under the 
two previous projects for TEVT, addressing the persisting problems that inflict the TEVT sector 
is important. First, a project approach allows a simple design with a strong emphasis on policy 
reform. Second, efforts across Pakistan to bring TEVT institutions under one organization will be 
supported. Punjab is leading in this effort through its effort to bring all TEVT activities under the 
technical education and vocational training authority and other provinces are watching this 
development  closely.  PGB  is  also  considering  merging  technical  education  under  the 
Department  of  Education  and  technical  and  vocational  training  under  the  Department  of 
Industries. Third, the devolution policy is affecting many government services, but has not yet 
affected TEVT provision. Therefore, a conducive environment is needed for PGB to allow 
greater autonomy to TEVT institutions and TEVT institutions to prepare to assume greater 
responsibilities to become more competitive and responsive to labor market needs. Finally, 
some of the fundamental elements necessary to enhance the effectiveness of TEVT institutions 
such as public-private partnership, counseling services, and exposure of teachers to industries 
can be achieved under a relatively simple investment loan.

Contribution of the subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
Given the strong linkage between poverty and low level of human development as measured by the human 
development index (HDI), the Government of Pakistan has set a major objective to accelerate gross domestic 
product growth, reduce unemployment, and reduce poverty in its Ten-Year Perspective Development Plan. In its 
Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) of December 2003, the Government recognizes education as a key 
ingredient for sustainable economic growth. Education is seen as a key to better quality of life, as well as a means to 
provide employable skills to prepare the population for employment and for future development of the country. In 
particular, the Government recognizes of basic education and skills development as key elements of poverty 
reduction. The plan and PRSP clearly identify priority areas for the education sector: (i) improving the literacy rate, (ii) 
accomplishing Education For All, (iii) improving the participation rate at the secondary level, (iv) producing higher 
education graduates responsive to the socioeconomic and technical needs of the country, and (v) improving the 
quality of education. 
 
Technical education and vocational training (TEVT) figures prominently in the development plan and PRSP as a 
strategy to produce skilled human resources that contribute to the country’s competitiveness. In the National 
Education Policy, the Government sets specific targets to expand TEVT facilities and improve opportunities for 
enrollment in quality TEVT programs. In addition to establishing more polytechnic and monotechnic institutes across 
the country, especially in Balochistan where TEVT facilities and opportunities are still limited, the Government plans 
to introduce job-oriented education and training at selected secondary schools throughout the country. To expand 
the base of the country’s skilled workforce, the Government has introduced a technical stream in 1,100 high schools 
with the aim of increasing the number of matriculation pass students who choose to study technical, commercial, and 
vocational subjects from 35% at present to 50% by 2011. In addition, existing facilities at high schools, technical and 
vocational training centers, commercial colleges, and polytechnic institutes are being used to conduct evening 
programs for out-of-school youth and dropouts to provide them with employable skills. These initiatives and activities 
directly support the Government’s policy and national priority to reduce poverty by providing quality technical 
education and vocational training, and expanding opportunities for accessing TEVT. 
 
The Project’s goal is to help reduce poverty in Balochistan by providing high-quality, relevant skills development 
programs and increasing access and equity to TEVT. One of the major objectives of the Project is to enhance access 
and equity to TEVT with a greater focus on women and rural poor. The Project will promote employment in small and 
medium enterprises by facilitating graduates’ access to microcredit. 
 
The proposed establishment of two new polytechnic institutes in Gwadar (boys) and Kzudar (girls), two potential 
growth centers, will greatly enhance access to TEVT. Together with the two existing polytechnic institutes, the 
polytechnics will produce about 1,000 technicians per year when in full operation. Many more rural poor students will 
benefit from the programs and facilities, as evening shifts will be introduced as well as nonformal livelihood training 
programs to cater mainly to women. About 500 polytechnic graduates will be able to access microcredit to start their 
own businesses. Considering that these TEVT graduates will be able to provide financial support to their families and 
generate employment for other people in the communities, the economic impact and benefits will be substantial.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                          Targeting Classification: Targeted Intervention 
In the past decade the incidence of poverty in Pakistan has increased sharply due to slow economic growth, decline 
in development spending, and lower agricultural outputs because of a severe drought. The proportion of the 
population living below the poverty line (defined by an intake of 2,350 calories per adult equivalent per day for the 
equivalent of PRs670 per capita per month in 1999 value) has increased from 26.6% in fiscal year (FY) 1993 to 
32.1% in FY2001, and deteriorated further to 38.2% in FY2003. Poverty in rural areas is normally higher than in 
urban areas; more than 75% of the poor live in rural areas. Although poverty increased in all four provinces of 
Pakistan during this period, the provincial rates varied. In FY1999 urban Sindh had the lowest level of poverty (16%), 
while rural NWFP had the highest incidence (42%). In comparison to NWFP, Balochistan has a lower poverty 
incidence (22.5). Characteristics of the poor in Pakistan include illiteracy, large family size, nonworking heads of 
households, and lack of physical assets such as land or livestock. Studies show that poverty incidence of highest 
among household heads with occupations such as day laborer in agriculture, construction, trade, and transport 
sectors. It is also high among the self-employed, including urban street vendors and rural sharecroppers.

disadvantaged groups who lack educational opportunities due to lack of facilities in or near their villages and districts. 
 
Educational opportunities are limited especially in rural areas. The Mahbub-ul-Haq Center for Human Development 
has developed a broad poverty index for Pakistan that takes into account deprivation in education and health, in 
addition to income. Among the three areas, poverty of education opportunities consistently ranked the highest from 
77% in 1970 to 58% in 1995. Pakistan has approximately 41 million adult illiterates and more are being added every

children are unlikely to attend school in the present situation.

D.   Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Gender discrimination is a key factor associated with poverty. Incidence of poverty among women is higher 
compared with men, and is characterized by low endowment of land and productive assets, unemployment, 
discrimination in the labor market, and limited access to economic options and political process. Pakistani women 
are generally discriminated against in almost all spheres of life, but the impact of discrimination in the education 
sector is most profound. The female literacy rate is only 29% compared with 55% for men. Gender inequality in 
educational opportunities is worse in Balochistan than in the other provinces and the national average. TEVT 
facilities and opportunities for women are equally limited. O f the 77 polytechnic institutes in the country only 10 are 
for women. The situation is somewhat better at the technical and vocational training level below polytechnics, with 
the number of vocational training centers for girls almost equal to that for boys. However, the number of trades or 
technologies offered by the centers for girls is limited and enrollment is also lower in the training centers for girls. 
Apart from cultural factors, socioeconomic factors play a role. In some rural training centers for girls, lack of public 
transportation services presents a big obstacle, even preventing girls from enrolling. 
 
In Balochistan the first Government Polytechnic Institute for Women (GPIW) was established under the ADB-funded 
Technical Education Project in 2002. Enrollments for the first 2 years closely approximate the project targets. As the 
polytechnic becomes better known and graduates prove successful, more students are likely to enroll. Based on the
